docs.lead_paragraph: Frustrated by managed care companies, hundreds of doctors gathered today at the American Medical Association's annual meeting here to debate forming a labor union. ''American physicians are angry, frustrated and exhausted over the intrusions of third-party payers into the day-to-day practice of medicine,'' said Dr. William G. Gamel, a delegate from Austin, Tex.
docs.abstract: Hundreds of doctors, frustrated by managed care companies, debate forming labor union at American Medical Assn's annual meeting in Chicago (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The shift to managed care in Latin America is largely the result of policies required by international donors, particularly the World Bank (Business Day, June 16). The bank's recipe generally mandates that markets be opened, health services privatized, and government expenditures reduced.
docs.abstract: Center for Health and Social Policy president Stephen L Isaacs letter on June 16 article holds shift to managed care in Latin America leaves care of poor, old and chronically ill people to overburdened local hospitals and doctors who lack resources to serve more people

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-9 Serbs Meet Deadline For Kosovo Withdrawal The last of some 40,000 Serbian forces left Kosovo a few hours ahead of NATO's deadline for withdrawal, in effect ending Yugoslavia's control over the province. The NATO Secretary General, Javier Solana, said that he had lifted the alliance's threat to resume bombing, formally ending the 78-day air war. A1 Leaders of the seven wealthiest nations and Russia met at a summit in Cologne and outlined a plan for ending eight years of war in the Balkans through a program of aid and political support, but said Yugoslavia must undertake ''democratic and economic reforms'' to take part. A8

docs.lead_paragraph: Legislation to protect the privacy of medical records is dying under pressure from insurance companies, health care businesses, law-enforcement officials and others lobbying Congress to preserve their access to sensitive information on patients. As envisioned, the bill was supposed to establish comprehensive Federal standards for the confidentiality of medical records. The goal of a uniform medical privacy standard was originally shared by consumer advocates and the health care industry, which now operates under rules that vary from state to state.

headline.main: Future Bleak for Bill to Keep Health Records Confidential

docs.abstract: Legislation to protect privacy of medical records is dying under pressure from insurance companies, health care businesses, law-enforcement officials and others lobbying Congress to preserve their access to sensitive information on patients; consumer and privacy advocates say bill, which has been changed amid spirited lobbying blitz, permits encroachment on privacy instead of protecting patients' confidentiality (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: IN the last year, dozens of patents have been issued to hopeful inventors who dream that their new version of the old-fashioned board game will one day become the next Monopoly. But in this age of Gameboy, is anyone still playing board games?

headline.main: Patents; In a world of cyber-this and video-that, can traditonal board games still gain attention?

docs.abstract: Dozens of inventors have patented new versions of traditional board games in last year, despite poor market for new games; Richard C Levy, who recently patented board of his game based on book Men Are From Mars, Women Are From Venus cites advantages of linking game to well-known book or product; M Ardell Olsen comments on patenting and self-publishing game based on Bible; Richard Recard plans to produce his recently patented science fiction board game himself and sell it over Internet (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses. To the Editor: The column missed the bigger picture. The discrimination in the workplace pales in comparison to what singles face at the Federal, state and local government levels.

headline.main: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits

docs.abstract: Paul J Gavin letter holds Daniel Akst's June 6 column misses bigger picture: that discrimination in workplace pales in comparison to what singles face at Federal, state and local government levels; contends tax laws are written to benefit married couples and families

docs.lead_paragraph: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses. To the Editor: Dan Akst described my life to a T, as well as that of many of my single gay and straight friends. Two of us drive cars that are 15-plus years old, because, among other things, we're taxed to the max to pay for the education of our married friends' children.

headline.main: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits

docs.abstract: Frank Post letter agrees with Daniel Akst's finding (June 6 column) that workplace favors married people with children
docs.snippet: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with...

docs.lead_paragraph: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses. To the Editor: The column made the point that single workers often do not fare well in advancing through the corporate ranks. That may be true, but at least single or childless workers have more control over their time -- and the potential to do more work if they choose. As someone who has been married for 21 years and is childless, I am glad I can make such choices about work. Still, it would be nice to gain a little more respect in the workplace.

headline.main: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits

docs.abstract: Larry Armstrong letter on Daniel Akst's June 6 column on how workplace favors married people with children over single persons
docs.snippet: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with...

docs.lead_paragraph: Do employers tilt the workplace toward workers who have children? In his column, ''In Defense of the Single and Childless'' (On the Contrary, June 6), Daniel Akst argued that they do -- whether by offering subsidized child care, pensions with survivors' benefits or health insurance for workers' dependents. The column drew varied responses. To the Editor: The column asserted that businesses reward their married employees more than their single ones. But that certainly doesn't seem to be the pattern at companies I know; in fact, I'd suspect that the opposite is true -- that it is the married employees who are penalized in terms of promotion and pay raises for being unable to work long hours.

headline.main: Married, With Children: The Workplace Benefits
